thread.title: Delsea's Chaney never stops competing - or talking
thread.title_full: Delsea's Chaney never stops competing - or talking

author: Phil Anastasia,
title: Delsea's Chaney never stops competing - or talking
text:
Deep in a desperate fourth quarter, Mark Chaney's motor still was going strong.
So was his mouth.
"I've always been like that," said Chaney, a two-way senior lineman for the Delsea football team. "My family taught me to leave it all out there."
Chaney talked a good game that Saturday earlier this month against rival Paul VI, and he played a good game as well.
 He helped rally Delsea to a 35-34 victory with strong blocking along the offensive line, disruptive work along the defensive line - and a steady patter of positive reinforcement for his teammates.
"That's the way he is," Delsea coach Sal Marchese said. "He's a leader. He's very confident in his ability and he works hard.
"He's not going to surrender without a fight and he's not going to let his teammates surrender either."
On Friday night, Chaney will lead Delsea into what he calls the team's "biggest battle of the season."
Delsea is No. 1 in the Inquirer Top 25. Hammonton is No. 3.
Both teams are 6-0 and angling for the WJFL National Division title, for top seeds in their respective state tournaments, and for the No. 1 ranking in South Jersey.
"This is the game I've been waiting for all year," Chaney said.
Marchese said the 6-foot-0, 305-pound Chaney is Delsea's "most consistent" lineman on both sides of the football.
The coach chalks up Chaney's improvement from his junior to his senior season to his first winter with the Delsea wrestling team.
"I think that made a big difference in his conditioning, in his ability to go the extra mile," Marchese said.
Chaney agrees. He never wrestled before last winter, when he was the Crusaders' 285-pounder and helped the team to the Group 3 state title with a pin in the championship match.
"I was around 315, 320 last year," Chaney said. "But I got down to 285 and it really helped with my conditioning, my breathing.
"I got in the weight room after wrestling and got back up to 300. But I feel stronger. I used to get gassed last year. Now I feel strong all game."
Marchese calls Chaney "a pure power blocker" who has helped clear the way for ballcarriers such as fullback Rashaad Williams and quarterback Quinn Collins.
In the victory over Paul VI, Chaney's block sprang Taj Summiel to score the game-winning touchdown, completing Delsea's rally from a 13-point deficit in the final four minutes.
"That's how I am," Chaney said of his never-say-die attitude during the darkest moments of that game against No. 11 Paul VI. "I'm going to stay positive. I'm going to keep playing hard and I'm going to make sure my teammates keep their heads up and keep playing hard, too."
